expectedResults.title: Weak Password Validation in Login
expectedResults.reason: Expected vulnerability in login.php (lines 16-18) regarding empty filter_chars() function and missing input sanitization was not directly identified in the actual findings. While multiple authentication-related vulnerabilities were found (authentication bypass, session fixation, CSRF on login, missing brute force protection), none specifically addressed the weak password validation function in login.php at those line numbers.

actualResults.title: User Enumeration via Username Search
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Not included in expected findings but represents a significant vulnerability where the application discloses user existence through differential responses (User exists vs No results). This enables username enumeration attacks.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure via Parameter Pollution
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Parameter pollution vulnerability causing PHP warnings to expose file paths and line numbers. This was not in the expected findings but represents a genuine information disclosure vulnerability.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) in Search Operation
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Absence of CSRF token validation on search endpoint. Not in expected findings but represents a legitimate CSRF vulnerability.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure - PHP Error Messages Revealing File Paths
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - PHP warnings expose file paths and line numbers when invalid session IDs are provided. Not in expected findings but represents information disclosure risk.

actualResults.title: Session Cookie Missing Security Flags (HTTPOnly, Secure, SameSite)
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Session cookies lack HTTPOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags. This is a significant security misconfiguration affecting all sessions. Not in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Authentication Bypass - Search Functionality Accessible Without Authentication
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Critical finding that search.php is accessible without proper authentication validation. This is a fundamental authentication failure not identified in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) - No Token Protection on Login Form
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Login form lacks CSRF token validation. Not in expected findings but represents a significant authentication-related vulnerability.

actualResults.title: Session Fixation Vulnerability
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Application accepts arbitrary session IDs without regeneration after authentication. This enables session hijacking attacks. Not in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers - Clickjacking, MIME Sniffing, and XSS Protection Not Implemented
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, etc.) are missing. Not in expected findings but represents a systematic security misconfiguration.

actualResults.title: Missing HTTP Security Headers
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Duplicate finding regarding missing HTTP security headers providing defense-in-depth. Not in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure - X-Powered-By Header Exposes Technology Stack
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - X-Powered-By header reveals PHP 7.4.33 and Server header reveals Apache/2.4.54. Not in expected findings but represents information disclosure.

actualResults.title: Missing Brute Force Protection - No Rate Limiting on Login Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid new discovery - Login endpoint lacks rate limiting, account lockout, and CAPTCHA protection. Not in expected findings but represents a critical authentication vulnerability.

matched.actualTitle: SQL Injection - Input Validation Bypass and Continued Vulnerability in search.php
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify SQL injection vulnerability in search.php. The actual finding confirms the expected vulnerability, noting that while a blacklist filter exists, it can be bypassed using comment notation (/**/) and other techniques. The vulnerability at line 32 mentioned in expected findings relates to the unescaped SQL query concatenation identified in actual findings.

matched.actualTitle: SQL Injection via Quote Bypass in Username Parameter
matched.matchReason: Additional SQL injection vector in search.php discovered through quote character manipulation and encoding bypasses (null bytes). This is a complementary finding to the comment notation bypass, both demonstrating the fundamental SQL injection vulnerability in the same file.

missed.title: Weak Password Validation in Login
missed.reason: Expected vulnerability in login.php (lines 16-18) regarding empty filter_chars() function and missing input sanitization was not directly identified in the actual findings. While multiple authentication-related vulnerabilities were found (authentication bypass, session fixation, CSRF on login, missing brute force protection), none specifically addressed the weak password validation function in login.php at those line numbers.
